title: Will Major League Baseball's (MLB's) Opening Day occur on 31 March 2022?
preds: They annouced an agreement but per others here need 2 weeks for spring training so April 7 is the start date.
MLB has announced date in April.
To my knowledge, opening day will be April 7th with an slightly extended spring training season prior to then.

Opening day is on 7 April as announced.
The probability of that being changed is zero, because minimum period of spring training of 2 weeks is necessary as per in 1990. https://www.cbssports.com/mlb/news/mlb-lockout-why-spring-training-likely-wont-start-on-time-and-when-opening-day-would-be-in-serious-jeopardy/

MLB announces revised 2022 regular-season schedule on 17th March.
https://www.mlb.com/news/mlb-revised-2022-regular-season-schedule
Per announcements, the opening day will be April 7
NYT says "deal" will see "play ball" early April.
News reports players union and MLB have reached a deal. Still a chance to back slide by have greatly increased the chances for baseball starting on time.
No change despite news of deal reached. I'll see other rationales before posting mine.

Now that things are delayed until April 14th and we're at March 10th, the chances of a last minute agreement and then rushed opening day seem exceedingly low. Even if they agreed today, I'm not sure they could get a game to happen by April 1, and I'm not sure there is any reason to do so rather than starting on the later date. Leaving open a very small chance for another week and then will go all the way to 0% (but realistically I'd still like it to be ~0.1%) https://www.mlbtraderumors.com/2022/03/mlb-announces-postponement-of-games-through-april-14.html

"The earliest the season will start is the second week of April, but there are large gaps on key issues in negotiations between the league and the players union. When the season will start is unclear." https://www.nbcsports.com/chicago/cubs/mlb-lockout-timeline-union-makes-first-proposal-cancelations
Apple just announced a Friday MLB 2-game exclusive deal to air games on Apple+, cannot see bargaining going much longer before they just sit down and agree.

https://www.cbssports.com/mlb/news/mlb-lockout-everything-to-know-about-baseballs-first-work-stoppage-since-1994-95/ History of past lock downs confirm durations from weeks to months.
Current timing and behavior of economics foretell a null posibility of an agreement
I read in the Washington Post today that Opening Day and the first two Series of the regular season have been canceled.

I'm not fully convinced this isn't a negotiation tactic that will still result in some agreement being reached soon. The question allows for even one game being played March 31st to count as Opening Day. Dropping down to 4%, will likely drop by 1% or so per week unless I see anything start to shift.
Maintream media in US reporting that Manfred has cancelled the season, for now...
It ha been announced that they will delay.

The commissioner announced Opening Day is cancelled. I still give it a 5% chance of recovering in the next few days and them rushing something. But it seems very likely it won't happen by March 31 now. https://www.foxnews.com/sports/mlb-players-reject-offer-deadline
Looks too far apart for comfort at this point.

As expected, the fake deadline was pushed back, currently until 5pm today but I wouldn't be surprised if it moved back again. The question now is how far it can possibly go for them to be able to have something they call an 'Opening Day' on March 31st and how far away they are. It seems the two sides still have some major disagreement but and making progress on a number of items. The MLB owners have stated they are "willing to miss a month's worth of games", which makes sense, as the financial hit for them over a month is likely smaller than for players. From what I understand the current minimum salary is $600k
The MLBPA is asking for and increase to $775k with $30k per year increase after that and they only want 10 teams in the playoffs,
The MLB has offered $700k minimum and a substantial bonus pool if 14 teams make the playoffs Increasing my chances up to 25% given the longer deadline and long day both sides put in yesterday. I think the most likely outcome is a resolution in the next week or so and either a rushed (and perhaps botched) opening day, or a slightly delayed opening day of April 1-5.
honestly I just have a gut feeling
https://www.twitter.com/feinsand MLB reports opening day will be delayed by there calculation

https://apnews.com/article/mlb-business-sports-francisco-lindor-baseball-ab3204ddd54cc628af1d2c4858f56836
Apparently everything is going swimmingly except the major issues.  This could go either way, as could the notion of shortening the preseason.

Another day without a deal. It could still happen tomorrow or Monday and opening day could still happen even if a deal is a few days late, but things are looking less optimistic every day that passes.

It appears that the two sides are still not near an agreement and the owners made it clear that games missed would not be rescheduled.  I'm revising my forecast downward.  While a lockout would result in lost revenue, the revenue is equally lost (but not proportionally lost) by both players and owners.  The lack of communication and the shared sense of a lose/lose situation may drive both sides to initiate a lockout to force one side to capitulate.

Read a bit more about this today and along with salary minimums and yearly increases there are some other items on the table like arbitration, the draft system, advertisements on uniforms and the length of the post season. This is a lot to get sorted in three days. I still think there is a chance they take longer but opening days still happens on March 31st. There is also the chance they reach and agreement but opening day is delayed because of something else, COVID, WW3, etc.

Finally read up on this a bit more beyond headlines, they're too far apart on bigger issues, particularly arbitration eligibility, service time manipulation, and revenue sharing. They are leaving so much money on the table, I still think it has a chance to start for that reason, but it's worth it for MLBPA to fight hard as these negotiations aren't frequent and make a huge difference. I suspect it won't be a long delay, but it feels like you need more than three weeks to get players ready, so we have about two weeks left to get a comprehensive deal in place. Good luck with that...

Increasing the chances as it seems both parties are at least at the right venue and discussing the right thing, they just haven't agreed on numbers yet. The Feb 28 'deadline' is a bit fake and I believe they are using that to force the issue but opening day could still be March 31st if an agreement was reached afterwards. From what I understand the current minimum salary is $600k
The MLBPA is asking for and increase to $775k with $30k per year increase after that
The MLB has offered $640k with $10k per season after that. This feels like the MLB is close to half way towards what the MBLPA is asking for, which makes me suspect we are close to a resolution.

"[...]
In fact, we are taking this step now [as of 18 Feb 2022] because it accelerates the urgency for an agreement with as much runway as possible to avoid doing damage to the 2022 season. Delaying this process further would only put Spring Training, Opening Day, and the rest of the season further at risk - and we cannot allow an expired agreement to again cause an in-season strike and a missed World Series, like we experienced in 1994. [...]"
(Robert D. Manfred Jr, Commissioner of Baseball)
https://www.mlb.com/news/cba-fan-faq https://www.mlb.com/news/mlb-mlbpa-second-straight-day-of-cba-talks The league and team owners appear to be terrified at this point in time. They admire the problem but don't solve it.
It seems both sides need a deal by Feb 28th to be able to maintain the scheduled March 31st opening day. With 8 days left, they still seem pretty far from that.

https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/2022/02/19/mlb-lockout-negotiations-timeline-spring-training/ While there is a lot to discuss there is a lot of pieces on the table to form an agreement with. With NFL concluded, the end of the Olympics very close, and omicron fading along with restrictions, I think the players and owners are recognizing missing opening day will be a very large black eye and dent in revenue.  I'm above 50/50 for the first time, but will have to see progress Tuesday or Wednesday before increasing likelihood.

Re-adjusting forecast. Signal: recent bargaining session on Thursday, 17 February lasted just 15 minutes. Translation: these two parties are far apart on their demands. Spring training is now delayed. https://www.espn.com/mlb/story/_/id/33322364/mlb-delays-start-spring-training-march-5-cba-negotiations-resume-monday The MLB and MLBPA will try again starting Monday and I am sure both sides are fully committed to playing for the fans.....but I tend to believe they are probably more committed to their individual financial health. This is an existential threat to the senior players, so I dont see any forward progress unless MLB capitulates.
Replacement players.   MLB will hold firm

The MLB's most recent counteroffer to the PA did not meet their needs and considering they feel they lost the last agreement, I expect the PA to hold out longer to attempt to gain back some of what they lost.

Dropped from 75% on the announcement that spring training has been delayed, mediation has been rejected and little progress is being made.
Expert opinion is that we still have another 10 days or so as there is still a need for a month of spring training - I don't quite understand it myself. 
Why can't we just run without training? everyone is in the same position?
Spring training is delayed and will therefore delay opening day.
the commissioner is already viewed negatively in the baseball community, his reputation is on the line
lowering: hard to find positive news.  Keeping over 50% due to the incentive that both sides ultimately want to play.

Pitchers and catchers were supposed to meet today, which was one of the signals I was watching.  There are now six weeks left before the start of the season.  If the players lose two weeks of spring training, I’ll lower my probability.
The incentives are quite the same as before, and some progress has been made, but not enough, and there is a lack of trust between the two sides,

The two parties are very far apart on what they want and neither has showed signs of budging. Even if an agreement is made prior to Opening Day, they need to build in some time for a modified Spring Training, to allow teams to officially set rosters.
league will realize competition for people's attention is fiercer than ever and make sure season starts

Saturday's proposal was much more broad and complete than anticipated. With this much on the table to discuss movement could put together a package more quickly.  Raising likelihood of a deal, but still not past 50/50. Anti-tanking and service time still not meaningfully addressed in the proposal.
https://www.msn.com/en-us/sports/mlb/players-union-unimpressed-with-mlb-s-new-proposal-start-of-regular-season-in-jeopardy/ar-AATMj1X?ocid=entnewsntp

2 articles: 
https://nypost.com/2022/02/11/mlb-players-growing-frustrated-by-lockout-negotiations/
https://www.espn.com/mlb/story/_/id/33260279/mlb-commissioner-rob-manfred-losing-games-lockout-disastrous-outcome Update based on the owners and MLBPA meetings on Thursday. Owners expected to issue an offer today (Saturday, 13 Feb). Two signals in these articles that draw my attention: the commish is dodging the question if the season will start on time; despite presenting an optimist perspective he generally states an agreement will be made in time to play the regular schedule (not necessarily on time, though). Second is the mention in NY Post article about a lack of trust between the two sides....primarily with the MLBPA. Indicates to me that the two sides are still not in a position to negotiate any deal that may be presented - potentially speaking past eachother. I am lowering my probability for an on-time start.
Last I checked, both parties like money.

The Scott Boras/Max Scherzer lash up would seem to continue influence this dialogue. Adjusting down until the next set of meetings to see if any movement on service time and tanking. Here is a great piece bringing a lot of the issues and history into one article.
https://www.athleticsnation.com/2022/2/9/22923829/mlb-lockout-negotiations-mlbpa-minimum-salary-arbitration

Both parties will eventually agree that the baseball season must be played, regardless of their off-field differences.  There's simply too much money that would left on the table if there were no stadiums to be filled with fans, nor tv ads to be sold to hungry audiences coming out of the COVID era.

Max Scherzer is a dominant voice on the MLBPA Executive Committee. The conditions he addresses in this article are not making progress. I will monitor the next proposal from owners, but until there is discussion on service time manipulation and anti-tanking I don't see negotiations moving to support a start of the season on time. https://www.msn.com/en-us/sports/mlb/manfred-and-the-mlb-owners-are-either-very-bad-at-their-jobs-or-are-lying/ar-AATC14w?ocid=entnewsntp

9 days until Spring Training is supposed to start, and the owners are meeting this week. I expect another package will be presented to the MLBPA at the end of this week, but...... I stand by my earlier prediction and base rate. MLBPA rejected the proposal to bring in a federal mediator. Labor Secretary Walsh has offered to participate which I am sure would also be turned down. MLBPA doesnt think they need an external mediator because their offer is fair to both sides. Bottom line is we are 9 days from ST start and the two sides cannot even agree on the PROCESS for negotiation, let alone the terms of an agreement. This pushes my prediction lower. We will re-assess at the end of the week once the MLB owners come out of their meetings this week.
Opening Day will be within two weeks of its scheduled date, but the players may feel attempting to exert leverage for a week or two is worth it.
Progress in the talks has largely been stalled, though there has not been particular new hostility.
The negotiators are still discussing minor issues and have yet to discuss the major challenges.

It is in both party's interests for games to be played.  However, COVID conditions and associated delays make a later opening day perhaps more palatable to the players and fans.  As of today, the negotiations have not concluded and don't seem closer to resolution.

The 1990 season and the COVID season have shown that the players can play with just 3 weeks training, and the fact that the COVID season was so recent means that a precedent has been set, and the players will be practiced at training on their own, and organizing training amongst themselves [1]. Players aren't paid during spring camps [1]so won't feel a rush to get back, whilst the owners will, as they will miss out on revenues from friendly games.  I think there is still a lot of time for an agreement to be reached without affecting opening day, however each passing day will hurt players and owners, yet it won't be until the start of March when to opening day will be threatened.  [1] https://www.espn.com/mlb/story/_/id/33167564/nearly-two-months-mlb-lockout-to-worry-spring-training-opening-day
[2] https://www.cbssports.com/mlb/news/mlb-lockout-why-spring-training-likely-wont-start-on-time-and-when-opening-day-would-be-in-serious-jeopardy/
Public Sporting areas are not operating at full capacity so I think this is the time they will stand their ground since they dont have as much to lose and its an opportunity to save money in salaries

It seems the parties are pretty far from even engaging on the right level, let alone reaching an agreement. For the NLF with fewer games, missing games is a bigger deal, but with the large amount of MLB games, missing a few has a proportionately smaller impact on the wallets of all parties. There have historically been three strikes that resulted in missed games in the MLB, so missing the first game is certainly precedented. It hasn't happened since 1995, which might make it seem less recently possible, but I believe given the current timeline, that is the most likely scenario. Assigning some weight to factors other than the strike stopping opening day from occurring such as COVID development, war, terrorist attacks, etc.
Given that pitchers and catchers are soon to report and that no plans have really been taken under way as reported by MLB itself, the season seems like it will likely be delayed.
Time is running out and both the owners and players still can’t agree on much of anything.

In 2020 there were 23 days from start of camp to opening day.  I have read that players and agents did not feel this was ample time.  Does not look like pitchers and catchers will report by 2/15. Clock is ticking...

At this point, players have already missed the start of spring training. Baseball club owners and the MLB Players Association reportedly are far apart in the negotiations. Despite how far apart the two sides are, presumably they both want the season to start on schedule. If that's true, it adds time pressure on both sides to reach an agreement. However, there is a precedent in baseball for a delayed start to the season. In 1990, opening day was pushed back by one week. I'm putting my initial probability at 70% that opening day will happen on schedule. https://www.cbssports.com/mlb/news/mlb-lockout-why-spring-training-likely-wont-start-on-time-and-when-opening-day-would-be-in-serious-jeopardy/
pressure is on to get back to "normal" , both players and owners are under the gun to get a contract done.

A pretty good and stark view of the current timing. Not as many available days to resolve as some might imagine.  Holding to current forecast. https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/2022/02/01/mlb-labor-negotiations-spring-training/
Seems less likely as time drags on.

Grapefruit league spring training games set to slated to start 26th Feb. Look out for this date to see whether things get started. However, these are pro sportsman, it isn't like they need to 'get in shape', they are just honing the sharp edge.
The athletic has an in depth article on the issue but I am not a subscriber but I understand that it ends with the statement "A new CBA is not close"
https://theathletic.com/3103051/2022/01/31/with-spring-training-likely-to-be-delayed-heres-why-mlb-and-the-players-union-are-still-far-apart/
I think that both parties will move over this month. Following two years of Covid disruptions is not the right time to cancel games. It will permanently hurt the franchise brands.
I have noted the base rate that others have discussed.
The comments of @SE_Meyer were particularly insightful though I disagree with the forecast (0/100% is a stretch for me at the most certain of times) I think that the two sides have come a long way in their bargaining. On some of the big issues (like pre-arbitration bonus pool and minimum salary) they are just squabbling over the final $$$

The key here is that both sides desperately want to get a deal done.  The amount of times games have been cancelled cause of CBA is only 3 times in MLB history (from what I saw).  There have been more lock-outs, but cancelling games out-right is rarer.  This will be adjusted based on whether spring training happens; a cancelled spring training would certainly be a bad harbinger.

9 strikes and lockouts (including current) since 1972. 4 lockouts. the 1990 lockout delayed spring training and delayed opening day by one week. 1980 strike (player led) was also about CBA - season went on and they agreed to discuss it later in the season. 1976 lockout was 17 days and noteably both sides agreed to start the season without a CBA. 1973 lockout (first ever) was over CBA - delayed opening camps but did not delay the regular season. 3 past lockouts and only 1 of them delayed opening day, so 66% chance of yes, it will occur on opening day. Sounds like CBAs are pretty important to owners and, according to the article i read, they wont lift the lockout until a provisional CBA is agreed upon. Provisional is a loose term through. Owners may be willing to call a cocktail napkin and crayon a "provisional CBA" in order to lift the lockout.  Everyone wants money and further delaying the season means further delaying the play. COVID impacts over the past 2 seasons have already made it tumultuous. Everyone wants the games to happen, on time (including spring training). Emotions will run high throughout the talks but in the end, there will be some sort of result that will lead to the first pitch on 31 March.
Commercial interest at stake is much greater, especially with COVID-19 pandemic gradually coming under control and the spectators willing to return to the arena across the country.

I think the disagreement is more fundamental than at any point in the history of collective bargaining in sports.
Net worth of franchises and of the league as a whole have peaked probably at record numbers, owners are now figuring out how to preserve relevance (everybody is afraid of losing, but billionaires are terrified) and turn brands into cash mashines with DRM, NFTs around.
Players on the other hand can hardly bargain for a higher salary: "human capital" in the franchises' balance sheets, the value of broadcasting rights and salaries have reached an outlandishly high level unthinkable a few decades ago, IMHO,  it's hard to drive things even higher in such times of economic uncertainty (an expression of massive inflation already?). Instead, the terms of contracts (cementing these good old days as long as possible come what may) with respect to length, minimum standards, salary composition (fixed vs. variable components), exit and amendment clauses, the agents' position and their slice etc will be the amount in dispute and key to a  bargaining success.
However, I do see the players and their association caught in a very weak position, they must be afraid of ending in the low wage sector of pro sports leagues, if MLB is on decline compared to popularity of NBA or NFL. With little or no lever, the costliest (albeit most self-destructive) way of standing their grounds is kind of a "nuclear option", which means no games, no cash flow, just negative publicity.
It remains to be seen how far the MLBPA is willing to go, but I'm a pessimist.

What @TDHesslink said...... Base rate: 4 lockouts in MLB history and the current is the first since 1990. Nine (9) total work stoppages with varying degrees of impact on spring training, start dates, and games missed. 
2021 lockout:  61 days, TBD
1990 lockout: 32 days, opening day pushed one week, no games missed
1976 lockout: 17 days, no games missed
1973 lockout: 18 days, spring training delayed, no games missed Base rate is that 1 in 3 complete lockouts resulted in a delayed start to the season = 33%.  I support the sentiment that MLBPA has learned from the 2020 / 2021 seasons the impact of delayed starts WRT injury, and will - regardless of the timing of an agreement - seek to preserve a three or four week spring training for the health of their players.  ESPN: "Injuries were a season-long issue when the start of spring training was altered by the pandemic in 2020 and 2021, and it will again be a concern if camps open late." "During the restart to the pandemic season in 2020, the 23 days between the start of summer camp (July 1) and Opening Day (July 24) wasn't enough time to get ready, at least according to many pitchers and their agents. In order to begin the 2022 regular season on time, and with less concern for injury, four weeks of spring are likely needed, according to league sources. That means camps need to open by March 3, approximately. It doesn't mean the sides can't agree on a shorter spring -- just like they did two years ago -- to keep Opening Day on March 31, it's just not ideal."
https://www.espn.co.uk/mlb/story/_/id/33167564/nearly-two-months-mlb-lockout-to-worry-spring-training-opening-day As of January 25th it is reported the talks are "progressing" with both sides making concessions and opening inroads to a deal - but this could be misplaced optimism based on the source. 
https://www.mlb.com/news/mlb-mlbpa-cba-talks-progressing On the other hand, many other sources seem to be taking a more pessimistic view of the negotiations - seemingly prepared for a delayed start if no agreement is made by February 1st.....so the next 25 hours. 
https://www.cbssports.com/mlb/news/each-mlb-teams-top-prospect-in-2022-royals-bobby-witt-jr-mariners-julio-rodriguez-more/ On that third hand that I own, I think there is an innate desire for the stewards of "America's National Past-time" to ensure that a 2022 season occurs, particularly because of the hardships experienced through two prior years of pandemic related hardship. That sentiment puts me at 50-50, beyond the base rate.  A more aligned message between MLB and external sports reporting sources will push me further toward a higher probability that the season will start - as planned - on March 31st.

Spring training is getting close.  If they don’t have a deal by spring training, the league might have to push back the start of the season to give players time to get into shape.  Like Trent, if there’s an agreement in time for a reasonable spring training, I’ll adjust my probability to above 50 percent.
Players seemed to have moved on already from initial demands. If already relenting, i expect players will want to move forward with the season as much as team owners.
I think there will be a negotiation between the owners and players prior to end of March 2022.
It seems less and less likely that owners and the MLBPA will reach terms in time to start Spring Training as planned.

Significantly softening opening position but not crossing 50/50. Major sports leagues lockouts are not completely unheard of. However, both NFL and MLB have prioritized the revenue and continuity of competitive games in regular seasons since the mid-90s. The NBA and NHL have been less committed to resolving issues to keep games going.
https://sports.yahoo.com/what-are-mlb-fans-in-for-heres-every-major-american-sports-work-stoppage-since-1994-165806863.html While that would provide base rate to support MLB has interest to returning to the playing field. The 2020 and 2021 seasons have shown how MLB can much more easily recover games in season to overcome lost games. 7 inning double headers, eliminating travel/rest days, expanding rosters to overcome players who can't play. While there is progress there is still a lot to work through.
https://www.cnbc.com/2022/01/27/mlb-lockout-talks-progress-but-clock-ticks-as-spring-training-nears.html
https://www.msn.com/en-us/sports/mlb/war-is-not-the-solution-for-baseballs-labor-woes/ar-AATg35B?ocid=BingNewsSearch Preparation for a season of baseball takes time especially for pitchers. As predominantly the highest revenue position in the sport, the players union will likely prioritize the health of pitchers in the return to playing. Spring training will happen. Likely a minimum of 21-28 days allowing pitchers to have 7-9 days of arm conditioning using a common throw no more than every 3 days prep cycle.   While a 7-inning double header and other game recovery methods might hurt individual stats and potential opportunities for salary bonuses, the players union will likely take the long view of a small impact to the start of the season. If an agreement is reached such that players report to Spring training by the first week of March I'll cross 50/50.
